div.sent: By geographical location, Bangladesh is located in the warm humid subtropical region.
To the north of the country is the Himalayas, and to the south is the funnel shaped Bay of Bengal.
Because of its geographical location, many natural disasters occur in the country.
Among the disasters are cyclone and tidal wave, flood, river erosion, draught, tornado and earthquake.
All parts of Bangladesh are more or less prone to natural disasters.
Natural causes bring disasters of various types to the different areas of the country.
For example, flood and river erosion occur in places where rivers flow.
Again cyclones and tidal waves strike in the coastal regions.
If the nature of the various natural disasters is understood, it is possible to take timely preventive and warning measures.
Cyclone is an area of low atmospheric pressure surrounded by a wind system blowing, in the northern hemisphere, in a counter-clockwise direction.
A corresponding high- pressure area with clockwise winds is known as an anticyclone.
In the southern hemisphere these wind directions are reversed.
Cyclones are commonly called lows, and anticyclones highs.
The radius of cyclone may be up to 500600 kilometres (km).
The eye of the cyclone is formed of light clouds and light winds.
The eye of the cyclone may be 20150 km.
The speed of wind around the centre may be 62118 km per hour.
As the equatorial region is relatively warmer, there is a low pressure.
Two types of seasonal winds'trade winds'from the northern and southern hemispheres cross each other in the region of low pressure over the equator.
These trade winds blow westward and toward the earth's equator in both the northern and southern hemispheres.
The trade winds occur between approximately latitude 30 north of the equator and latitude 30 south of the equatorthe tropics.
The trade winds are a major part of the general circulation pattern of the earth's atmosphere.
Instead, they blow from the northeast in the northern hemisphere and from the southeast in the southern hemisphere.
Such interacting region is called the torrid zone.
At the points of intersection of winds from opposite sides, numerous small whirlpools or eddys are created.
The low pressure created in the areas of these whirlpools cause the cold heavy wind to flow forcefully from the surrounding areas of high pressure.
Because of the rotation of the earth, the cold heavy air flows into the eddy with a rotational force.
As the whirlpool moves northwards, under the influence of Coriolis force, more forceful whirlpools are created.
Some of these whirlpools then change into low pressure or depression.
The longer the depression stays in the ocean or sea, the stronger it gets.
Its main force is the massive water of the ocean, the wind blowing over the area contains water vapour.
As the water evaporates it takes in the energy in the form of latent heat of vaporisation.
When the vapour mixes with the air, the latent heat enters the air and increases its force.
At these times the air high up is cool.
As the rising hot air containing water vapour comes in contact with the cold air the vapour condenses into clouds.
As the latent heat is retained in the atmosphere, there is increased turbulence.
With the increase in temperature, the air pressure in the depression site decreases and cyclone is formed.
As these cyclones cross the coastal regions, under its influence strong wind, floods and tidal waves occur.
During cyclones, the swelled up ocean or seawater forms high waves as they cross the coastal regions.
This is tidal wave.
There is evidence that there exists a direct relationship between tidal waves and cyclones, and earthquake and volcanic eruptions in the ocean bed.
The stronger the cyclonic force, the higher is the tidal waves.
The cyclone that struck the coastal region of Bangladesh on 01 November 1976 brought in tidal waves as high as 13.72 metres.
As the cyclone crosses the coastal area, the tidal waves cause colossal damage to life and property.
Of all the damage done by the combination of cyclone and tidal waves, 90 percent is due to tidal waves alone.
Bangladesh is within the cyclone prone area.
Hence, it is noted that at different times round the year cyclones strike some parts of the country.
It is not always that the cyclones strike the coastal areas, but sometimes crosses over the coastal areas to strike much interior areas of landmass.
The cyclones are sometimes accompanied by tidal waves.
Under the influence of strong winds the seawater swells up and moves towards the coast as tidal waves.
Cyclones and tidal waves have brought colossal damage to Bangladesh numerous times in the past.
Timing of Natural Disaster: In Bangladesh, natural disasters'cyclones and tidal waves usually strike around AprilMay (Boishakh and Jaistha), and October November (Kartik and Agrahayan).
After the cyclone is formed due to depression, it moves with the huge body of water towards the coast.
Nature of Damage by Cyclone and Tidal Wave: Most of the people along the coastal belt of Bangladesh are poor.
During natural disasters these people suffer the most.
Majority of the non-brick made houses (kaacha houses) are damaged during the cyclone.
As most of the houses have tin roofs, these roofs are blown away by the storm and the houses collapse.
People die by being buried under the mud walls or by injury caused by flying tin roofs.
Not only the houses are destroyed, cattle, and other domestic animals also die.
After losing everything, people are sometimes forced to live under the open sky.
All the essentials of life, such as grains, food, articles of daily use, clothes, books and copies, are washed away with the tidal waves.
Many trees are also uprooted, crops are damaged, animals and birds die, all these lead to shortage of food.
Cyclones also damage telephone, telegraph and electric poles with disruption of these essential services.
There is no communication with the other parts of the country and people have to live in pitch darkness.
At times, offices, courts, industries, schools, collages, dams, bridges, railway tracks, and foot walks are damaged too leading to extreme suffering of the people.
During tidal waves the water bodies and tubewells are contaminated and so there is scarcity of drinking water.
In the post disaster period people drink contaminated water and so suffer from diseases, such as, diarrhoea, dysentery, typhoid, cholera, jaundice, and so on.
Besides, the loss of cattle and other domestic animals, people suffer financially too.
The environmental imbalance left behind by the natural disaster leads to many diseases.
So different preventive drugs and oral rehydration saline have to be distributed.
As most water bodies are contaminated, water should be boiled well before drinking.
If there are wells, then water-purifying tablets should be used as preventive measure.
Pre- disaster Management: It is possible to keep the damage to a minimum if appropriate watchfulness and warning measures are taken prior to the disaster.
But because of early warning and other pre-disaster measures the damage was much less.
In Bangladesh, the Disaster Management Bureau is doing this job of forewarning.
Generally, if there is a possibility of a cyclone, the Meteorology Department announces the same frequently over radio and television.
That is why it is essential that in all disaster high-risk areas, specially in fishing boats and trawlers, there should be a radio in each.
As soon as the people receive forewarning of a cyclone, they should prepare to leave their homesteads and move to safe places for shelter.
The immovable property should be covered with heavy weight, and left in the house.
Water pitchers should be filled with clean drinking water.
The mouth of the pitcher should be tightly and carefully closed with fitting lids or polythene paper, and buried under the soil.
Cattle and other domestic animals should be taken along to the safe place that may be a high land, or strong building.
Money and other valuables should be wrapped in polythene and buried.
Some dry flattened rice, fluffed rice, molasses, and water should be taken along to the cyclone shelter.
Listen continuously to the warning announcements on the radio and prepare accordingly.
After listening to the warning over the radio, the fishermen should refrain from going out to sea for fishing.
Below are the warning signals and what they mean or indicate.

Before leaving the homestead to go to the shelter centre it is advisable not to leave behind any valuable thing.
All fire should be put out before moving out.
Management during Disaster: From the beginning to the end of the disaster, during the stay in cyclone shelter, people should have sympathetic attitude.
Sharing of things raises hope among the under privileged people.
Post-disaster Management: In the post-disaster time the major issue is to ascertain the loss of life and property, and rehabilitation of the affected people.
It is necessary to list the affected people and note the extent and type of damage incurred.
Building houses for the homeless; distributing food, clothes, medicines, and short term loan; and financial help become essential.
To trace out the lost people, and to bury the dead animals and humans become imperative during the early stages of post-disaster period.
Early disposal of dead bodies will save the environment from pollution and spread of communicable diseases.
It is also necessary to co-ordinate the relief activities by non- government organisations.
If the shelters are built with this aim, then the shelters will not fall into disuse, and be abandoned.
In Bangladesh, natural disasters strike several times a year, and has changed the lifestyle of the people living in the coastal areas.
Currently, natural disaster has become a regular phenomenon, so creating awareness among the inhabitants has become necessary.
Every year natural disasters strike Bangladesh to cause severe natural and financial problems.
This calls for the formation of disaster management committee in every village and through discussion, decide on the ways and means to tackle these disasters.
Early warning about the time when disaster may strike is one of the ways that people can save themselves.
The discussions will include creating awareness about the warning signals and what they indicate, pre-disaster management, and ways to preserve food and other items.
People should learn swimming.
Besides sari, women should keep at least a set of salwar and kameez.
The people should be alerted through miking about moving to the cyclone centre in time.
This calls for creating awareness, co-operation and sympathy among all.
